image.altText: Spirit IV docked at Macquarie Wharf in Hobart

props.synopsis: Spirit of Tasmania IV has at last arrived in the state, eight years after the Tasmanian government embarked on a project to replace the two ships currently in operation. The other new ferry remains in Finland, where they were built.

title.children: 'She's beautiful': New Spirit of Tasmania ferry arrives in Hobart

image.altText: A white truck, pursued by multiple police vehicles, drives on the wrong side of the road at night time.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian man has been refused bail after engaging Tasmania Police in an hours-long pursuit during which he drove a stolen truck through Launceston on blown-out tyres.

title.children: Police chase 'a bit Fred Flintstone, a bit Blues Brothers', witness says

image.altText: A very skinny horse standing in a paddock

props.synopsis: The RSPCA's prosecution panel has "extensively reviewed the facts" and decided not to lay charges after three thoroughbred horses once owned by a former Tasmanian attorney-general, were found emaciated.

title.children: No charges laid over emaciation of horses once owned by Vanessa Goodwin

image.altText: Josh Willie a man in his 40s with pale skin and dark hair. He is sitting in front of a radio microphone and wearing headphones.

props.synopsis: Listening to the new Tasmanian Labor leader's first media interviews, you'd be forgiven for thinking little had changed. But the subtle shifts in language suggest a change in the party's direction.

title.children: Josh Willie's tough task to find winning policy shifts for Tasmanian Labor

props.synopsis: Tassie's wildlife is already under increasing pressure, but are we unknowingly adding to their demise? Â Have you bought a poison to get rid of rodents? The problem is it might not just be them you get rid of. Airlie Ward talks with reporter Bec Pridham.

title.children: TassieCast: Are we unwittingly killing our native wildlife with poison baits?

image.altText: An emperor penguin lies down in the snow, behind a small grey fluffy penguin chick.

props.synopsis: Scientists say there is emerging evidence of abrupt and potentially unstoppable changes in the Antarctic environment, heightening the risk of significant sea level rise and the extinction of species.

title.children: Scientists warn of 'abrupt changes' taking place in Antarctica

image.altText: A 12yo girl with dark circles around her eyes and skinny arms, holds up an old photo of her where she's smiling.

props.synopsis: Hospitals in Gaza are having to divert resources to treating surging cases of malnutrition as starvation takes hold across the strip. Meanwhile, children who need treatment are waiting to be evacuated.

title.children: Malnourished Huda needs treatment outside of Gaza â but she can't leave

image.altText: A man with short hair wearing a yellow, white and black sweater sits in a classroom smiling, with children in the background.

props.synopsis: After never seeing primary school teaching as a career path, Ryan Brown now believes he's found his "calling", but he's one of just two male classroom teachers at his Canberra primary school.

title.children: In a male teacher drought, Ryan is an endangered breed

image.altText: Depop scam graphic

props.synopsis: Amy thought she was pretty tech-savvy, until she watched as a scammer tried to transfer $13,000 out of her savings.

title.children: Victim watches on as scammer transfers $13k from savings to card

image.altText: People in FBI jackets load up a car with evidence boxes

props.synopsis: John Bolton served in the US president's first administration as national security adviser, but later became critical of Donald Trump.

title.children: FBI raids home and office of vocal Trump critic John Bolton

image.altText: A group of first responders standing beside the tour bus on its side.

props.synopsis: Injuries from the bus crash ranged from head trauma to broken arms and legs.

title.children: At least five killed after tour bus from Niagara Falls to New York City crashes

image.altText: AI image: An orange, red and black coloured Aboriginal-style dot painting created with the generative AI Midjourney.

props.synopsis: We asked ChatGPT to create authentic Indigenous artworks and stories. Experts say what it produced â while "quick, easy and cheap" â represents a profound threat to First Nations cultures.

title.children: We asked AI to make Indigenous art. What it produced shows its great threat

image.altText: A woman wearing a yellow and white flower above her ear, a large black necklace and a green and yellow patterned dress.

props.synopsis: Samoans will vote for their next government on August 29 in elections that have been defined by soaring cost-of-living pressures, blackouts and political turmoil.

title.children: Fate of the Pacific's 'Iron Lady' could rest on a $50 box of chicken

image.altText: Glass shattered on the floor of a house

props.synopsis: Three people are stabbed following an alleged home invasion in Melbourne's west, police say.

title.children: Three stabbed in home invasion in Melbourne's west

image.altText: Esther Perel

props.synopsis: Sharing feelings and downloading troubles with others occurs naturally when these close connections are maintained.

title.children: Unpicking the mental load of 'mankeeping' amid a male loneliness epidemic

image.altText: A man wearing a tie walking with a woman outside.

props.synopsis: Accusations of lies and collusion along with profanity-laden secret phone recordings have taken centre stage in the third week of the high-profile trial against Matt Wright.

title.children: 'Flat-out lie': Witnesses accused of lying to protect Matt Wright during trial

image.altText: A black and white photo of Pamela Digby holding the arm of Winston Churchill on the steps of a church surrounded by wellwishers.

props.synopsis: Pamela Digby was just 19 years old when she agreed to marry UK prime minister Winston Churchill's only son, Randolph, on the day they first met. The union, short as it was, changed the course of her whole life.

title.children: Was this aristocrat a ruthless social climber or the UK's 'secret weapon'?

image.altText: A massive open cut gold mine with a series of large haul trucks operating.

props.synopsis: Kalgoorlie's 4.5 kilometre-long Super Pit mine comes back from the brink, striving to reclaim its crown as Australia's biggest-producing gold mine.Â

title.children: Record gold price spurs renaissance of 'super' 3,500km tunnel mine

image.altText: A man with olive complexion, brown hair that rests on forehead, head resting on chin, sitting and looking to left.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest has heard that a man who shot his ex-partner in the stomach before taking his own life had made attempts to seek help in the weeks prior to the tragedy.

title.children: Police missed 'red flags' prior to attempted murder-suicide, inquest hears

image.altText: A man is led through a crowd of people and TV cameras by police officers in brown uniforms

props.synopsis: Ranil Wickremesinghe was taken into custody on Friday for allegedly misusing public funds while in office.

title.children: Former Sri Lankan president arrested for alleged corruption offences

image.altText: Donald Trump visits a temporary migrant detention center informally known as "Alligator Alcatraz"

props.synopsis: The order said that authorities must remove "all generators, gas, sewage, and other waste and waste receptacles that were installed to support this project", within 60 days.

title.children: Judge orders dismantling of Trump's 'Alligator Alcatraz' detention facility

image.altText: Cameron runs holding a football during a game. He wears a white and jersey with red stripes.

props.synopsis: At the peak of his football career, Cameron Vazzoler's immune system started attacking his nerves and he had to learn to walk again. But now he is back on the field.

title.children: Football star returns to field after tackling rare autoimmune disorder

image.altText: Koala mum and joey sitting cuddled together on a thin gumtree branch.

props.synopsis: Six joeys have been born in a wild koala breeding program that boasts a 100 per cent success rate. The babies are cute, but a hands-off approach is vital if they are to survive in the wild.

title.children: First joeys born in unique koala matchmaking program

image.altText: A scuba diver with a shopping basket underwater.

props.synopsis: Scientists relocate a precious collection of coral and fish to a temporary home while a new Queensland aquarium is built. Â

title.children: Coral collectors move world's largest living display in four-year effort

image.altText: an older man and woman inside a door frame

props.synopsis: It took more than a year for Kathleen Whelan's husband Alan to get an assessment for in-home aged care. Ten months later, he has seen no assistance.

title.children: Wife told to abandon husband at hospital to get home care assessment

image.altText: Alexei Popyrin looks down under blue skies in all white clothing at Wimbledon.

props.synopsis: The increasing demand on tennis players has led to burnout, but Australia's Alexei Popyrin turned to science-fiction books and Ed Sheeran as therapy ahead of the US Open, which begins on Sunday.

title.children: How Ed Sheeran and George Orwell helped Alexei Popyrin handle burnout

image.altText: Josh Willie a man in his 40s with pale skin and dark hair. He is sitting in front of a radio microphone and wearing headphones.

props.synopsis: Listening to the new Tasmanian Labor leader's first media interviews, you'd be forgiven for thinking little had changed. But the subtle shifts in language suggest a change in the party's direction.

title.children: Long road back for Tasmanian Labor under Willie must start now

image.altText: Harry Grant with his hands on his head

props.synopsis: Melbourne Storm captain Harry Grant is handed a two-match ban for a shoulder charge as Bulldogs coach Cameron Ciraldo continues to be puzzled by a controversial Bunker ruling.

title.children: Storm skipper Grant suspended as Bunker drama leaves Dogs puzzled

image.altText: A three image composite of Terrance Stamp, Winnie the Pooh and Ash Centra.

props.synopsis: We've collected some of the most jaw-dropping, eyebrow-raising or mildly confusing quotes in the news this week. See how you go with our first quote quiz.

title.children: ABC Quote Quiz: Who said it, and what were they on about?

image.altText: close up of a truffle.

props.synopsis: Growers say the price of truffles is justified due to their rarity, especially as drought conditions this year have made them even harder to find.Â

title.children: Demand for truffles continues to climb despite $3,500 per kilo price tag

image.altText: England players celebrating a try together

props.synopsis: Women's Rugby World Cup hosts England start their tournament with a bang, recording a 69-7 win over the United States, and coach John Mitchell warned there is more to come.

title.children: England 'will get better' after scoring 11 tries in World Cup opener

image.altText: A woman looks fierce as she propels herself along the ice on her sled.

props.synopsis:
A team of Australian women are making history at the first ever Para Ice Hockey Women's World Championships.

Â

title.children: From collisions to 'fisticuffs', the women making history in para ice hockey

image.altText: Ruby sits on a white bed wearing jeans and a black singlet and gently smizes at the camera.

props.synopsis: In a "tale as old as time", author Ruby Jean Cottle lived with severe endometriosis symptoms for years before getting a diagnosis or treatment. Almost two decades on, she credits her chronic illness with helping her write her debut vampire romance novel.

title.children: How fatigue, pain and surgery 'paved a path' for this Aussie novelist
